üçÉ The flower that tastes like spice and grows like courage I grew my first nasturtium during a season of uncertainty.
I had no garden‚Äîjust a cracked terracotta pot and a heart that needed soft things.
The seeds burst open quickly, like they‚Äôd been waiting all along.
And when the first red bloom of ‚ÄòEmpress of India‚Äô unfurled, it felt like a whisper from a braver version of myself.
Nasturtiums (Tropaeolum majus) aren‚Äôt delicate damsels.
They‚Äôre fire-colored, pepper-flavored, and bold-spirited‚Äîthriving where the soil is lean and the gardener unsure.
To grow them is to remember that even in overlooked places, beauty not only survives‚Äîit thrives.
üåø What Are Nasturtiums? Nasturtiums are flowering annuals native to South America, adored for their round, shield-like leaves, vivid edible blooms, and resilient spirit. They‚Äôre equally at home in cottage gardens, city balconies, and overgrown corners yearning for color.
Whether trailing or compact, they charm bees and hummingbirds, spice up your salads, and remind you that wildness is a form of wisdom.
üå∏ A Portrait of Popular Nasturtium Varieties Let me introduce you to the girls‚Äîeach with her own mood, color, and secret strength.
‚ú∂ ‘Empress of India’ Color: Deep crimson red Foliage: Blue-green matte Type: Compact, upright Energy: Regal. Steadfast. A bloom that wears its fire quietly. Best For: Containers, edge plantings, edible elegance Care Tip: Avoid overwatering‚Äîshe prefers slightly dry spells to stay vivid and compact. ‚ú∂ ‘Alaska’ Series Color: Red, gold, tangerine Leaves: Cream-marbled variegation Type: Upright or softly trailing Energy: Cool contradiction‚Äîfrosted foliage, warm blooms Use Tip: Perfect for edible flower borders or moon gardens Care Tip: Needs more sun than others to keep variegation crisp and non-leggy. ‚ú∂ ‘Jewel Mix’ Color: Scarlet, peach, butter yellow (double or semi-double) Type: Bushy Energy: Playful, generous, joyfully chaotic Best For: Summer bouquets, color therapy, childlike wonder Care Tip: Deadhead often to prolong the blooming season‚Äîit loves attention. ‚ú∂ ‘Tip Top’ Series Traits: Compact and floriferous Flowers: Upward-facing, making eye contact Best In: Window boxes, places close to the heart Why I Love Her: A tidy rebel. She knows where she stands. Care Tip: Pinch back early to encourage dense, upright growth. ‚ú∂ ‘Whirlybird Mix’ Color: Open-petaled, no nectar spurs Best Use: Culinary‚Äîeasy to harvest and wash Poetic Note: Her openness is not vulnerability‚Äîit‚Äôs grace in action. Care Tip: Ideal for raised beds‚Äîlow foliage helps you harvest easily. ‚ú∂ ‘Gleam’ Series Habit: Vining, trailing Perfect For: Hanging baskets, vertical softscapes Spirit: Overflowing joy, an invitation to spill over the edge Care Tip: Give her something to climb, and she‚Äôll reward you with fountains of bloom. ‚ú∂ ‘Black Velvet’ Color: Near-black burgundy, velvety Mood: Sensual, poetic, mysterious Design Tip: Pair with pale cosmos or cream roses for contrast drama Care Tip: Best in partial shade‚Äîhelps deepen her dramatic color. ‚ú∂ ‘Peach Melba’ Color: Creamy yellow petals blushed with cherry Energy: Sweet but discerning Place Her: Beside a tea bench, among herbs and quiet company Care Tip: Protect from heavy rain to avoid petal bruising‚Äîshe‚Äôs delicate in the loveliest way. ‚ú∂ ‘Canary Creeper’ (Tropaeolum peregrinum) Type: Perennial in warm zones, twining vine Flowers: Frilly yellow, bird-like Growth Style: Climbs fences, climbs moods, climbs hesitations Why I Plant Her: Because not all growth is rooted‚Äîsome of it reaches. Care Tip: Needs a sturdy trellis and regular trimming to keep from overtaking its neighbors. üçΩÔ∏è Culinary Delights & Garden Companionship Nasturtiums are the ultimate edible flowers‚Äîa full sensory experience:
Leaves: Peppery like arugula, perfect in open-faced sandwiches Flowers: Bright, spicy, symbolic Seeds: Capers of the gentle gardener (pickle them!) They also repel aphids and whiteflies, making them a wonderful companion plant for vegetables like beans, squash, and tomatoes.
üå± Growing Tips for Nasturtium Success Sunlight: Full sun = boldest blooms Soil: Poor to average; too rich = too leafy Water: Low-maintenance once established Sowing: Direct in soil after last frost Harvest: Regular picking = more blooms üí¨ FAQ: Growing and Enjoying Nasturtiums Q1: Are nasturtium flowers and leaves really edible?
Yes, both are edible. The flowers are mildly spicy, while the leaves have a sharper, peppery flavor.
Q2: Do nasturtiums require fertilizer?
No‚Äîfertile soil leads to more leaves and fewer blooms. Nasturtiums prefer lean, well-draining soil.
Q3: Can I grow nasturtiums in pots or hanging baskets?
Absolutely. Use compact varieties like ‚ÄòTip Top‚Äô for containers, and trailing types like ‚ÄòGleam‚Äô or ‚ÄòCanary Creeper‚Äô for baskets.
Q4: Do nasturtiums attract pollinators?
Yes, they are magnets for bees, hoverflies, and hummingbirds.
Q5: Will they come back next year?
They are annuals but often self-seed freely. Let a few flowers go to seed for surprise blooms next season.
Q6: Are nasturtiums good companion plants?
Yes! They repel pests and can protect vegetables in companion planting schemes.
üåº Closing Petals To plant a nasturtium is to plant a declaration‚Äîof color, flavor, and quiet defiance.
She thrives on neglect and still blooms with abandon.
She isn‚Äôt needy. She‚Äôs knowing.
She reminds us, especially women, that resilience doesn‚Äôt have to be loud to be real.
Sometimes, the most powerful thing we can do is bloom anyway.
With soil beneath my nails and sunlight on my lips,

title: A Gentle Guide to Crocus Varieties

A Gentle Guide to Crocus Varieties ‚Äî little poems of color, blooming through the frost
I still remember the first crocus that rose in my garden ‚Äî a single purple flame pushing through the cold, half-frozen soil. No fanfare. No audience. Just a soft, certain bloom in a world that hadn‚Äôt yet remembered how to be warm.
It didn‚Äôt shout. It whispered.
And in that whisper, I heard: Begin, even if the world isn‚Äôt ready yet.
This is what crocuses teach me, year after year: how to return, how to be small but strong, and how to bloom softly, in your own rhythm.
üåø What is a Crocus? Crocus is a small, perennial flowering plant grown from corms, not bulbs. Belonging to the Iris family, crocuses are best known for:
Being one of the earliest spring flowers Producing vibrant blossoms in white, purple, gold, or striped patterns Some blooming in autumn, including the legendary saffron crocus (Crocus sativus) These flowers are the gentle revolutionaries of the garden ‚Äî tiny, but defiant in beauty and hope.
To plant a crocus is to place a secret sunrise beneath the soil.
üå∏ Spring-Blooming Crocus ‚Äì Hope in Bloom These crocuses bloom when the earth still dreams in white. Their bravery touches something ancestral in me ‚Äî the kind of strength that lives inside soft things.
‚úø Crocus vernus The classic large-flowered crocus, often seen in curated spring borders.
‚ÄòJeanne d‚ÄôArc‚Äô: pure white, named after a warrior girl wrapped in peace.
Care Tip: Prefers full sun and well-drained soil. Avoid overwatering to prevent corm rot.
‚ÄòPickwick‚Äô: purple-striped elegance ‚Äî like a Victorian letter pressed in petals.
Care Tip: Plant in groups for maximum impact; tolerates partial shade.
‚ÄòGrand Maitre‚Äô: smoky lavender, dignified and gentle.
Care Tip: Thrives in well-drained, moderately fertile soil; mulch in colder climates.
‚úø Crocus chrysanthus Often called ‚Äúsnow crocus,‚Äù these are petite and fragrant, ideal for naturalizing.
‚ÄòBlue Pearl‚Äô: a soft whisper of morning.
Care Tip: Prefers moist soil during growing season; great for under trees or lawns.
‚ÄòCream Beauty‚Äô: candlelight in flower form.
Care Tip: Plant in full sun to partial shade; good drainage essential.
‚úø Crocus tommasinianus (“Tommies”) Beloved by bees and early pollinators, and perfect for grassy meadows.
‚ÄòRuby Giant‚Äô: deep violet, blooming with purpose.
Care Tip: Naturalizes well in lawns; mow only after foliage dies back to allow corms to store energy. Plant spring crocuses in clusters for the most poetic effect ‚Äî like a scattered stanza of color across the lawn.
üçÇ Autumn-Blooming Crocus ‚Äì Wisdom in Bloom Autumn crocuses bloom when the world begins to turn inward ‚Äî golden light, falling leaves, and flowers that bloom like second chances.
‚úø Crocus speciosus Large, showy blooms with violet petals and bright orange stamens. A true surprise in the fading year. **Care Tip:** Prefers sunny, well-drained spots; mulch lightly to protect from frost. ‚úø Crocus sativus (Saffron Crocus) The source of the world‚Äôs most expensive spice ‚Äî saffron. - Harvested at dawn, each flower yields just **three crimson threads**. - To me, it represents **sacred femininity**: hidden strength, slow labor, and quiet worth. **Care Tip:** Requires well-drained, sandy soil and full sun; keep soil moderately moist during growth. ‚úø Crocus pulchellus Refined and modest, these flowers bloom like old songs sung softly. **Care Tip:** Tolerates partial shade; best planted in humus-rich, well-drained soil. ü™ª Botanical & Wild Crocus ‚Äì Heritage in Bloom These lesser-known species are deeply rooted in the wild soul of crocus ‚Äî often smaller, earlier, and more expressive.
Crocus sieberi ‚ÄòTricolor‚Äô: a painter‚Äôs dream ‚Äî violet, white, and sunshine yellow in a single petal.
Care Tip: Prefers full sun and well-drained soil; great for rock gardens and alpine beds.
Crocus banaticus: asymmetrical and fierce, like an iris who doesn‚Äôt play by the rules.

title: A Gentle Guide to Hyacinth Varieties
content:
üå∑ A Gentle Guide to Hyacinth Varieties A love letter to the flowers that taught me to return to myself.
When I first planted hyacinths, I wasn‚Äôt seeking color ‚Äî I was searching for quiet. The garden had become my sanctuary, and hyacinths, with their thick, fragrant blooms, were like reminders in the soil: that rebirth is slow, and softness is not weakness.
There is something deeply feminine about hyacinths. They arrive early, often before the world is ready. They do not wait for permission to bloom. In their fragrant silence, they remind us: you are allowed to take up space ‚Äî and to smell amazing while doing it.
üå∏ Types of Hyacinths & Their Stories Each hyacinth variety carries a subtle message, a hue of emotion, a scent of season. Here are my favorites, told not just as plants, but as metaphors for the women we are becoming.
üåº Single Hyacinths Confident. Classic. Unapologetically fragrant.
‚ÄòDelft Blue‚Äô ‚Äî Gentle sky blue petals that smell like nostalgia. Ideal for calm spaces.
Care tip: Keep soil evenly moist and avoid direct harsh afternoon sun to prolong bloom life.
‚ÄòPink Pearl‚Äô ‚Äî Blush pink and quietly radiant. Softness, redefined.
Care tip: Prefers well-drained soil and moderate sunlight; protect from strong winds.
‚ÄòCity of Haarlem‚Äô ‚Äî Creamy yellow, like sunlight before noon. Understated, but powerful.
Care tip: Water moderately, allowing topsoil to dry slightly between watering sessions.
‚ÄòWoodstock‚Äô ‚Äî Deep magenta-purple. Dramatic, mysterious, unforgettable.
Care tip: Thrives in partial sun; avoid overly wet soil to prevent bulb rot.
‚ÄòPeter Stuyvesant‚Äô ‚Äî Indigo-toned and deeply scented ‚Äî the poet of the garden.
Care tip: Plant in full sun to bring out the richest color and fragrance.
üå∫ Double Hyacinths Layers of bloom, like layers of healing.
‚ÄòHollyhock‚Äô ‚Äî Crimson folds that feel like velvet. Bold femininity.
Care tip: Ensure good air circulation around plants to keep petals fresh.
‚ÄòMiss Saigon‚Äô ‚Äî Dusky plum, sultry and contemplative.
Care tip: Prefers slightly cooler spots to maintain flower longevity.
‚ÄòGeneral Kohler‚Äô ‚Äî A powdery blue heirloom that speaks in whispers.
Care tip: Mulch lightly in cooler climates to protect bulbs over winter.
These flowers are for women with stories ‚Äî those who‚Äôve grown new petals after old ones were torn away.
üåø Multiflora Hyacinths Loose, wild, deeply alive.
‚ÄòWhite Festival‚Äô ‚Äî Soft white stalks with multiple flower heads. Ideal for natural-style gardens.
Care tip: Water deeply but less frequently; allow soil to dry between waterings.
‚ÄòBlue Festival‚Äô ‚Äî Relaxed blue tones. Less structured, more free.
Care tip: Prefers full sun to part shade; avoid soggy soil conditions.
These are perfect for cottage gardens, or for those of us unlearning perfection.
üå± Miniature & Wild Hyacinths Quiet resilience in delicate form.
‚ÄòAnastasia‚Äô ‚Äî Tiny lilac blooms. Think woodland fairytales.
Care tip: Great for rock gardens or edges; keep well-drained soil.
‚ÄòMarie‚Äô ‚Äî Small, dreamy blue flowers for windowsills and fairy corners.
Care tip: Perfect for pots and indoor growing; keep moderate moisture.
These miniature varieties remind me: being small doesn‚Äôt mean being insignificant.
üå∏ Symbolism & Feminine Strength Hyacinths are often associated with rebirth, inner strength, and healing. As one of the first blooms of spring, they symbolize emotional resilience ‚Äî the ability to return, gently but firmly.
‚ÄúLike many women I know, hyacinths appear soft, but carry centuries of survival in their scent.‚Äù
In a world that rewards loudness, hyacinths choose presence over noise. They reclaim space quietly ‚Äî just like many of us do, every day.
üåø How to Grow Hyacinths: A Ritual, Not Just a Task Growing hyacinths is like writing a letter to your future self. They require nothing extravagant ‚Äî only time, quiet, and intention.
üå± When to plant:
In autumn (September‚ÄìNovember), before the ground freezes.
‚òÄÔ∏è Light requirement:
Full sun to partial shade.
üå∑ Soil type:
Well-drained, moderately fertile, slightly alkaline. Add grit if your soil retains too much water.
üåº Depth & spacing:
Plant bulbs 4‚Äì6 inches deep and 3‚Äì4 inches apart.
üíê Indoors or outdoors?
Both! Force them indoors in glass vases or plant in containers for balcony beauty. Place where their scent can greet you ‚Äî by your door, kitchen window, or bedside.
Need more planting help? Try my article on How to Grow Bulbs with Intention üåü Hyacinths as Self-Care: A Bloom Ritual When I force hyacinths indoors in January, it’s a promise: I will still believe in spring, even when nothing outside shows it yet.
Cut hyacinths in a glass bottle by your writing desk, your altar, or even beside your bathtub. Let their scent become your daily reminder that healing doesn‚Äôt need to be loud ‚Äî it just needs to be consistent.
‚ùì FAQ: Your Hyacinth Questions Answered Q1: What are the best hyacinths for fragrance?
Single-flowered varieties like ‘Delft Blue’ and ‘Pink Pearl’ are the most intensely scented.
Q2: Are hyacinths safe for pets?
No. Bulbs contain oxalic acid and can be toxic to cats and dogs if ingested. Keep out of reach indoors and outdoors.
Q3: Can hyacinths grow indoors?
Yes! You can force them indoors in a vase with water or in containers with soil. They bloom beautifully and scent a room like perfume.
Q4: How long do hyacinths bloom?
Typically 2‚Äì3 weeks in spring. Extend bloom time by placing them in cool, partially shaded spots once they begin to flower.
Q5: Will hyacinths come back every year?
They can, but bloom size often diminishes over time. In warmer climates, treat them as annuals. In colder regions, they can naturalize with proper care.
Q6: Do hyacinths symbolize anything?
Yes ‚Äî they are symbols of rebirth, heartfelt sorrow, and deep inner strength. In Greek mythology, they were born from love and loss ‚Äî just like many of us.
üå∑ Final Thought ‚ÄúIf I ever lose myself again, I will follow the scent of hyacinths.
They bloom not because the world is ready ‚Äî but because they are.‚Äù
Plant one. Wait. Heal slowly. And when it blooms, you‚Äôll remember: you bloomed too.
‚Äì Jojo Len

title: A Gentle Guide to Begonia Varieties
content:
There is a quiet kind of beauty that doesn‚Äôt beg to be seen ‚Äî it simply is. That is how I feel about begonias.
One sits on my writing desk now, half in shadow, its velvet leaves veined with silver like old secrets. It hasn‚Äôt bloomed in months, and yet it soothes me more than any bouquet. In a world that asks us to be loud, bright, and constantly productive, begonias teach a different lesson: to grow gently, in our own time.
With over 2,000 species, Begonias are among the most diverse houseplants in the world. Each type speaks its own language of light, resilience, and color. Some are flamboyant performers; others are quiet philosophers. All, in their way, are reminders of how strength and softness can coexist ‚Äî not as opposites, but as companions.
I‚Äôve found pieces of myself in each one. Let me show you.
üåø Rex Begonias: The Bold Artists of the Leaf World
Begonia rex, the so-called ‚ÄúKing,‚Äù is a sovereign of foliage. Spiraled leaves unfurl like a whispered declaration of self-worth. Deep burgundy, lavender smoke, moon-silver veins ‚Äî each leaf a story, each curl a revolution.
A Rex doesn‚Äôt ask for permission to be bold. She simply is.
I keep mine near the mirror where I brush my hair. She reminds me that beauty is not always soft, and softness is not always silent.
Light: Bright but indirect
Water: Let the soil dry slightly, then water with intention
Humidity: She loves mist like skin loves silk
Tip: Avoid cold drafts and soggy soil. Her roots prefer consistency and warmth.
üå∫ Tuberous Begonias: The Summer Bloom Queens
Begonia √ó tuberhybrida enters like a theatre goddess ‚Äî in trailing gowns of flame and coral, blushing pinks, apricot creams. She‚Äôs unafraid of her bloom. And neither should we be.
She reminds me that joy isn‚Äôt meant to be hidden. It‚Äôs meant to spill.
Perfect for hanging baskets by balconies or paths you pass often. These blooms love to be noticed ‚Äî and they reward the gaze with riotous color.
Light: Partial shade or morning sun
Mood: Extravagant joy
Tip: Deadhead faded flowers to keep the show going and prevent rot.
üçÉ Rhizomatous Begonias: The Quiet Healers
These plants are earthbound thinkers. Rhizomatous begonias don‚Äôt hurry, and they don‚Äôt boast. They creep, they sprawl, they root deep.
Mine lives beside my reading chair, in a corner where no other plant thrives. But she does. And she tells me, in the language of new leaves, that healing doesn‚Äôt have to be loud.
There is power in quiet reclamation. And in the act of staying.
Common types: Begonia bowerae, Begonia ‚ÄòEscargot‚Äô
Light: Filtered or indirect light
Water: Water when the top inch of soil dries
Tip: Use shallow, wide containers to give rhizomes room to stretch.
üå∏ Angel Wing & Cane Begonias: Graceful Resilience
Named for their winged leaves speckled with moonlight, Angel Wing Begonias are both upright and ethereal. They bloom in soft drifts of coral, blush, and red ‚Äî but it‚Äôs their posture I admire most.
She grows upward like a woman who has finally learned to take up space.
I prune mine with care. Not to control her, but to offer shape ‚Äî the way we refine dreams, not shrink them.
Light: Bright, indirect light
Water: Let top inch dry, then soak evenly
Tip: Pinch stem tips regularly to encourage fullness and flowering.
üåº Wax Begonias (Semperflorens): Everyday Radiance
Often overlooked for their humility, Wax Begonias are the keepers of quiet consistency. With waxy, rounded leaves and petite blooms in red, white, or pink, they are the steady flame rather than the spark.
She is the love that doesn‚Äôt need grand gestures ‚Äî just presence.
If you‚Äôre beginning your plant journey, begin here. These are the friends who stay ‚Äî even when the season shifts.
Light: Full sun to part shade
Water: Keep evenly moist but not soggy
Tip: Feed monthly during active growth to support blooming.
üå± Trailing Begonias: Cascading Romance
Begonia boliviensis, with its arching stems and delicate blooms, brings softness to any structure. She doesn‚Äôt stand tall ‚Äî she drapes. She adorns. She lets gravity shape her beauty.
To fall isn‚Äôt failure ‚Äî it is another kind of grace.
Perfect for high shelves, terraced walls, or anywhere you want to introduce motion and lightness.
Light: Bright but not harsh
Water: Keep soil lightly moist
Tip: Choose hanging baskets with drainage and water thoroughly when top inch is dry.
üå∫ Begonias as Feminine Icons: A Quiet Manifesto
What I‚Äôve learned from my begonias, more than anything, is that there is no one way to grow. Some stretch tall. Some cling low. Some dazzle. Some rest. Some bloom only when no one is looking.
Isn‚Äôt that what it means to be a woman, too?
We contain seasons. We hold contradictions. We bloom wildly or not at all ‚Äî and still, we are whole.
In my slow mornings, pruning or misting or simply sitting beside them, I feel seen. Not for who I show the world ‚Äî but for who I am when I‚Äôm still.
If this resonated, you may also love: A Gentle Guide to Lavender Varieties üß† FAQ: All About Begonia Varieties
Q1: What types of Begonia are best for beginners?
A: Wax Begonias and Angel Wing Begonias are low-maintenance and beautifully forgiving.
Q2: Can begonias grow indoors?
A: Yes! Rex, Angel Wing, and Rhizomatous types are particularly well-suited to indoor life with indirect light.
Q3: Are Begonias toxic to pets?
A: Sadly, yes. Keep begonias away from curious cats and dogs.
Q4: Do all Begonias bloom?
A: Technically yes, but some are prized more for foliage than flowers. Like people, not all their beauty is visible.
Q5: What is the symbolic meaning of Begonias?
A: Begonias often symbolize individuality, harmony, and caution ‚Äî but in our garden of meaning, they whisper softness, sovereignty, and slow awakening.
üíå A Final Petal
If no one has told you lately, let this be it: You don‚Äôt need to bloom to be beautiful. Your worth isn‚Äôt seasonal.
Be the Begonia on the windowsill. The one growing quietly, leaning gently toward the light.
With warmth always,
Jojo Len

üåº A Season of Return: Why I Plant Daffodils Every Year There‚Äôs a quiet defiance in the daffodil.

Even after the long night.
As someone who‚Äôs found healing in the rhythm of tending soil and spirit, I see each daffodil as an archetype‚Äîa symbol of feminine power, soft strength, and radical joy.

ü©∑ 4. Double Daffodils Key trait: Layers of petals and sometimes a frilled crown.

üåô 5. Triandrus Daffodils Key trait: Nodding flowers in clusters, often with translucent petals.

‚òÄÔ∏è 6. Cyclamineus Daffodils Key trait: Reflexed petals like windswept hair.

There‚Äôs something radical about blooms that don‚Äôt belong anywhere but here.

üå∑ Daffodils & the Feminine Season of Becoming Every daffodil is a mirror of becoming:

Most common reasons: too little sun, overcrowding, or cutting foliage too early.

Bloom time ranges from early to late spring depending on variety. A well-planned garden can have daffodils blooming for 6‚Äì8 weeks.

What Are Snapdragons? Snapdragons are perennial or biennial flowers cherished for their uniquely shaped blooms resembling little mouths opening and closing ‚Äî a delicate dance with the sun. After a day‚Äôs work, I often find solace sitting beside my Snapdragons, watching their tiny mouths open wide to the sun‚Äôs warmth. They remind me that it‚Äôs not only okay to open ourselves ‚Äî it is necessary. To speak, to feel, and to bloom fully in our own time is an act of courage and grace.

A5: Regular deadheading (removing spent flowers) encourages continuous blooming and helps maintain plant vigor.

With gentle strength and blooming courage,

A Gentle Guide to Tulip Varieties ‚Äî blooming, as an act of quiet revolution.
There‚Äôs a moment every spring where the world exhales ‚Äî and tulips lead the breath. They rise not in chaos but in clarity. Silent, colorful testaments to rebirth. To choosing softness after surviving the frost.
In this guide, I invite you into the story of 8 tulip varieties, each with its own rhythm, hue, and emotional resonance. Beyond their botanical names lies a garden of metaphors for growth, womanhood, and reclaiming gentle power.
üå∑ Why I Return to Tulips Every Spring Tulips, for me, are not just flowers.
They are small poems tucked into soil. Letters to a future self who remembers how to hope.
When I plant tulip bulbs in the chill of autumn, I’m not gardening ‚Äî I’m trusting. Trusting that beauty will return, even if I can‚Äôt see it yet. Trusting that healing, like tulips, begins invisibly.
Spring brings their bloom ‚Äî and with it, a reminder:
Softness is not the absence of strength. It’s the shape of survival when it blooms.
üå∏ 8 Tulip Varieties & Their Soulful Echoes Each tulip variety feels like a different version of myself in bloom. Below are the ones I return to, season after season.
1. Darwin Hybrid ‚Äî The Bold Bloom Examples: Apeldoorn, Pink Impression Flowering: Mid to late spring Style: Large, upright, vivid colors Essence: Confidence, visibility, redefinition This is the tulip I plant the year I say no without guilt and yes without shrinking.
Perfect for those embracing personal growth in bold color.
Care Tip: Plant bulbs 6-8 inches deep in well-drained soil. Water moderately during growth, but reduce watering once leaves yellow to avoid rot.
2. Triumph ‚Äî The Quiet Power Examples: Negrita, Strong Gold Flowering: Mid spring Style: Classic cup shape, excellent structure Essence: Balance, calm resilience, gentle certainty I see these as the introverts of the garden‚Äîstrong, contained, but full of inner color.
Care Tip: These tulips thrive in full sun and well-drained soil. Remove spent flowers to encourage bulb strength for the next season.
3. Parrot ‚Äî The Untamed Spirit Examples: Black Parrot, Estella Rijnveld Flowering: Late spring Style: Ruffled, flamboyant, unpredictable Essence: Wild beauty, artistic courage, defiance These tulips bloom like they have stories to shout. And I love them for it.
Care Tip: Parrot tulips prefer rich, well-drained soil and should be protected from strong winds due to their delicate petals.
4. Fringed ‚Äî The Delicate Edge Examples: Fancy Frills, Crystal Star Flowering: Mid to late spring Style: Frilly, elegant, lace-like edges Essence: Elegance, protection, layered softness Like the woman who speaks softly but leaves an unforgettable impression.
Care Tip: Keep soil moist but not soggy. Mulch in fall to protect bulbs through winter, especially in colder climates.
5. Double Late ‚Äî The Gentle Luxe Examples: Angelique, La Belle √âpoque Flowering: Late spring Style: Peony-like, multi-petaled, romantic Essence: Tenderness, nostalgia, feminine grace These are the blooms of slow Sunday mornings and handwritten letters to your past self.
Care Tip: Provide plenty of sunlight and avoid overcrowding to maintain air circulation around these lush blooms.
6. Greigii ‚Äî The Humble Joy Examples: Red Riding Hood Flowering: Early spring Style: Compact, striped foliage, joyful shape Essence: Playfulness, beginner‚Äôs joy, grounding She‚Äôs not tall, but she‚Äôs vibrant. A reminder that small things can be radiant.
Care Tip: These tulips enjoy sun and partial shade. Their foliage adds interest even after flowers fade.
7. Viridiflora ‚Äî The Subtle Muse Examples: Spring Green, Artist Flowering: Late spring Style: Green-streaked petals, minimalist and modern Essence: Clarity, reflection, serene individuality These tulips feel like morning light through linen curtains ‚Äî unassuming, yet transformative.
Care Tip: Viridiflora tulips prefer fertile soil and full sun for best color contrast.
8. Single Early ‚Äî The Brave Beginning Examples: Purple Prince, Apricot Beauty Flowering: Early spring Style: Simple, strong-stemmed, reliable Essence: Hope, beginnings, foundational strength I plant these for the version of me who keeps showing up, even when the ground is still cold.
Care Tip: Plant these bulbs in well-drained soil, and water well during growth. They make excellent cut flowers.
üåø Garden Feminism in Bloom To tend to flowers is to tend to oneself. Gardening ‚Äî especially slow, intuitive gardening ‚Äî becomes a form of self-reclamation. Each tulip is a way I return to the parts of me that were once buried, overlooked, or waiting for light.
I don‚Äôt grow tulips to impress.
I grow them to remember how to feel deeply and live gently.
üåº FAQ ‚Äî Tulip Growing Questions for Gentle Gardeners What is the best time to plant tulip bulbs? Tulip bulbs should be planted in fall, ideally between late October and early November, before the ground freezes.
Do tulips come back every year? Some tulips are perennial, such as Darwin hybrids, but many are best treated as annuals for consistent blooms. Replanting yearly ensures a vibrant spring display.
How long do tulips bloom? Each tulip bloom lasts about 7‚Äì14 days, but by mixing early, mid, and late varieties, you can enjoy color from early March to late May.
Are tulips beginner-friendly? Yes! Start with Triumph or Single Early varieties for a reliable and rewarding floral experience.
Can I grow tulips in containers? Absolutely. Use well-drained soil, a sunny spot, and pots deep enough for bulb roots (at least 6‚Äì8 inches deep).
What do tulips symbolize? Tulips often represent rebirth, feminine strength, and emotional honesty. Each variety carries subtle symbolic tones‚Äîexplore what resonates with you.
üíå Final Thought May your garden bloom like your inner self ‚Äî with grace, wildness, softness, and strength.
And if you forget how to begin again, just look to the tulips.
They always remember.
With mud on my hands and poetry in my spine,
Jojo

A: Absolutely! Especially the Profusion series, which is disease-resistant, long-blooming, and easy to care for‚Äîideal for novices.

üç´ 3. Cosmos atrosanguineus The Scented Secret

Appearance: Old rose fragrance with modern, repeat blooms Personality: Beloved for fragrance, charm, and timeless beauty Care whisper: Loves full sun and good airflow. Keep soil moist but not soggy. üå∫ 6. Climbing Rose ‚ÄúShe is the adventurous spirit, reaching toward the sky.‚Äù
Appearance: Long, vigorous canes with blooms scattered like stars Personality: Ideal for trellises, arches, fences ‚Äî a vertical poem Care whisper: Guide canes gently, tie securely, and maintain airflow to keep pests away. üå∑ 7. Miniature Rose ‚ÄúShe is the small wonder, a jewel in any corner.‚Äù
Appearance: Compact, with delicate, petite flowers Personality: Perfect for pots, balconies, or cozy indoor spots Care whisper: Easy to pamper with regular watering and a bright, warm nook. üåø 8. Groundcover Rose ‚ÄúShe is the quiet blanket, spreading gentle joy.‚Äù
Appearance: Low-growing, sprawling with abundant, colorful blooms Personality: Hardy, disease tolerant, ideal for covering spaces with a soft carpet of color Care whisper: Minimal fuss; water during dry spells and enjoy her steady, cheerful bloom. Extra Tip: She benefits from light pruning in early spring to refresh growth and shape. She cushions the earth with a soft blanket of life and color.
üå± JojoLen‚Äôs Mindful Rose Care Tips Sunlight: Roses flourish with six or more hours of direct sunlight daily. Water: Keep soil moist but avoid wet leaves to prevent mildew. Water deeply but less frequently to encourage strong roots. Soil: Enrich your garden bed with organic compost and ensure excellent drainage for happy roots. Pruning: Remove dead, diseased, or weak branches early each spring to invite fresh, vibrant growth. Pests: Maintain garden cleanliness and gently discourage pests using natural remedies like diluted soap water sprays. üå∏ A Garden of Patience and Presence To care for roses is to honor moments ‚Äî waiting, watching, and gently nurturing life.
Each unfolding petal is a soft reminder that growth happens in its own time.
May your garden become a sanctuary of softness and slow beauty, where roses and your heart both bloom peacefully.
If you‚Äôre drawn to what roses represent‚Äîbeauty, defiance, memory‚Äîyou might like this letter I once wrote: I Am Not Your Rose üåø With gentle love,
Jojo Len
‚ùì Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) About Rose Gardening Q1: What is the easiest rose variety for beginners?
Hybrid Tea and Shrub Roses are excellent for beginners due to their beauty and relatively forgiving nature.
Q2: How much sunlight do roses need daily?
Roses thrive best with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to promote strong growth and vibrant blooms.
Q3: How often should I water my roses?
Water deeply but infrequently ‚Äî about once or twice a week depending on weather. Avoid wetting leaves to prevent disease.
Q4: When is the best time to prune roses?
Early spring, just as buds begin to swell, is ideal for pruning to encourage healthy new growth.
Q5: How can I prevent common rose pests naturally?
Keep your garden tidy, encourage beneficial insects, and use gentle sprays like diluted soap water to deter aphids and mites.
